elements.content: One novel fulvene ligand HL was synthesized successfully by an aroylation reaction of substituted cyclopentadienyl anion. The coordination chemistry of fulvene ligand HL is investigated. The study demonstrated that the fulvene-type ligand HL could be used as multidentate or chelating ligand to coordinate transition metal ions into a coordination polymer or a supramolecular complex. One novel one-dimensional Ag(I)−fulvene organometallic coordination polymer, namely, [Ag(HL)(H2O)]SbF6 (1) and one Co(II) complex, namely, Co(L)2·2C2H5OH (2), with an unusual seven-membered metallo-ring unit were synthesized successfully based on HL and L, respectively. In the solid state, complex 2 adopts a novel hydrogen bonded one-dimensional chain motif.

In the solid state, complex 2 adopts a novel hydrogen bonded one-dimensional chain motif.

elements.content: This study demonstrates that the new fulvene-type of ligand HL is capable of coordinating metal ions into either a coordination polymer or molecular complex. One new Ag(I)-containing coordination polymer (1) and one Co(II)-containing H-bonded supramolecular complex (2) were synthesized successfully, respectively, based on it.

elements.content: Within the field of inorganic−organic supramolecular chemistry, efforts to simultaneously utilize transition metal ions and organic spacers to form new extended framework structures through coordination or hydrogen-bonding interaction have yielded diverse new materials, some of which have potential applications such as catalysis, nonlinear optics, gas separation, magnetic devices, and molecular recognition. Currently, the most efficient approach to prepare framework materials is via direct chemical combination of functional inorganic and organic components, a method that has proven quite fruitful.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Within the field of inorganic-organic supramolecular chemistry, efforts to simultaneously utilize transition metal ions and organic spacers to form new extended framework structures through coordination or hydrogen-bonding interaction have yielded diverse new materials, some of which have potential applications such as catalysis, nonlinear optics, gas separation, magnetic devices, and molecular recognition. Currently, the most efficient approach to prepare framework materials is via direct chemical combination of functional inorganic and organic components, a method that has proven quite fruitful.

elements.content: In contrast to the well-developed coordination chemistry based on bidentate and polydentate organodiamine ligands, coordination chemistry based on fulvene molecules has received considerably less attention. It is well-known that fulvene is one of the most important classes of ligands in organometallic chemistry and widely used in the construction of organometallic complexes. A continuing project in our laboratory has been the development of coordination polymers or supramolecular complexes generated from the fulvene molecules and inorganic salts. As a result of the multifunctional fulvene ligands and the coordination preferences of transition metals, new types of organometallic coordination polymers and supramolecular complexes, in part with open channels and solid state luminescent properties, have been obtained. Our previous study demonstrated that the structural information of these types of ligands is rich (Scheme ):  they process two functionalities with the carbonyl and cyano moieties. As we know, the cyano functional group on the aromatic ring is a good candidate for coordination bonding as has been exploited in the self-assembly of Ag−supramolecular architectures. In addition, the 1,4-diketone structural unit in this type of ligand could be used as a chelating group to bind transition metals into seven-membered metallo-ring complexes that might be not achievable by other kinds of 1,4-diketone derivatives. To establish reliable synthetic and principles of coordination chemistry of fulvene ligands of this type, a wide database of the experimental procedures and the preferred coordination patterns is required. This encourages us to continue this project and expand this interesting coordination chemistry based on fulvene molecules. Herein, we wish to report one new fulvene ligand HL (Scheme ), one Ag(I)-containing coordination polymer [Ag(HL)(H2O)]SbF6 (1), and one Co(II)-containing H-bonded supramolecular complex Co(L)2(C2H5OH)2 (2) based on HL and L, respectively.

elements.content: Materials and Methods. 3-Cyanobenzoyl chloride and 6,6‘-dimethylenefulvene were prepared according to literature methods. AgSbF6 and Co(OAc)2·2H2O (Acros) were used as obtained without further purification. Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets, and spectra were obtained in the 400−4000 cm-1 range using a Perkin-Elmer 1600 FTIR spectrometer. 1H NMR data were collected using a JEOL FX 90Q NMR spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in δ relative to TMS. Element analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Model 240C analyzer. All fluorescence measurements were carried out on a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorimeter (Varian, Australia) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

 Materials and Methods. 3-Cyanobenzoyl chloride and 6,6‘-dimethylenefulvene were prepared according to literature methods. AgSbF6 and Co(OAc)2⋅2H2O (Acros) were used as obtained without further purification. Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets, and spectra were obtained in the 400-4000 cm-1 range using a Perkin-Elmer 1600 FTIR spectrometer. 1H NMR data were collected using a JEOL FX 90Q NMR spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in δ relative to TMS. Element analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Model 240C analyzer. All fluorescence measurements were carried out on a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorimeter (Varian, Australia) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature.

elements.content: Synthesis of HL. A solution of 3-cyanobenzoyl chloride (2.00 g, 12.5 mmol) in anhydrous ether (20 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of substituted cyclopentadienyl anion (18.8 mmol) in anhydrous ether at 0 °C, which was derived from 6,6‘-dimethylenefulvene (18.8 mmol) and 4-biphenyllithium (18.8 mmol) in anhydrous ether. The mixture was stirred overnight at room temperature. The solvent was then reduced to about 10 mL under vacuum. Hexane was added, and an orange solid precipitated. The solid was washed with hexane several times and stirred in HCl (5% in water) overnight. The final product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (CH2Cl2 /hexane, 2:1) to afford an orange crystalline solid (1.73 g, 56%). IR (KBr pellet) ν (cm-1) = 3100(w), 2990(m), 2250(vs), 1620(vs), 1590(vs), 1555(vs), 1525(s), 1485(vs), 1445(s), 1365(s), 1350(s), 1200(s), 1120(s), 1100(s), 935(s), 915(m), 800(m), 765(m), 730(m), 695(m). 1H NMR (90 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C, TMS):  δ = 17.75 (s, 1H, OH), 7.9−7.2 (m, 19H, -biphenyl), 6.97 (s, 2H, -C5H2), 1.60 (s, 6H, -CH3). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C36H26O2N2:  C 83.30, H 5.01, N 5.40; found:  C 83.69, H 5.26, N 5.32.

elements.content: Synthesis of 1. AgSbF6 (12.0 mg, 0.035 mmol) was added to a solution of HL (15.5 mg, 0.03 mmol) in 15 mL of benzene. After about 30 min of stirring at room temperature, the mixture was heated under reflux for several minutes. After filtering, the resultant yellow solution was introduced into a 7 mm diameter tube. After the sample stood at room temperature for around one week, yellow crystals of 1 were obtained (59%). IR (KBr pellet) ν (cm-1) = 2980(s), 2850(m), 2295(s), 2255(s), 1620(vs), 1550(vs), 1520(vs), 1415(vs), 1350(vs), 1200(s), 1170(s), 1100(m), 930(m), 765(s), 655(vs). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C36H28AgF6N2O3Sb:  C 49.08, H 3.18, N 3.18; found:  C 49.28, H 3.51, N 3.35.

elements.content: Synthesis of 2. A mixture of HL (10.4 mg, 0.02 mmol) and Co(OAc)2·2H2O (3.0 mg, 0.01 mmol) in anhydrous EtOH (15 mL) was refluxed for 5 min and allowed to cool. The clear red solution was allowed to stand at room temperature for about one week. Deep red crystals of 2 were obtained, and they were washed with hexane and dried in air (90%). IR (KBr pellet) ν (cm-1) = 3500(br), 3105(w), 2990(m), 2850(m), 2255(s), 1585(s), 1565(vs), 1525(s), 1445(m), 1410(s), 1360(m), 1325(s), 1200(w), 1140(w), 1120(w), 1095(w), 910(w), 765(m), 730(m), 690(w). elements.content: Single - Crystal Structure Determination. Suitable single crystals of HL and 1 and 2 were selected and epoxied in inert oil onto thin glass fibers. X-ray intensity data were measured on a Bruker Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer system (MoKα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). The first 50 frames were recollected at the end of the process to monitor crystal decay; no significant decay was observed in any case. The raw frame data for HL and 1 and 2 were integrated into SHELX-format reflection files and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects using SAINT. Corrections for incident and diffracted beam absorption effects were applied using SADABS. All structures were solved by direct methods and refined against F 2 by the full-matrix least squares technique. Hydrogen atoms were calculated and refined as riding atoms; all non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Crystal data, data collection parameters, and refinement statistics for HL and 1 and 2 are listed in Table . Relevant interatomic bond distances and bond angles for them are given in Tables −4.

Structural Analysis of HL. Ligand HL was prepared in moderate yield as an orange crystalline solid by the reaction of 3-cyanobenzoyl chloride with corresponding alkyl-substituted cyclopentadienyl anion, which derived from 6,6‘-dimethylenefulvene and 4-biphenyllithium in ether at 0 °C (Scheme ). HL is soluble in common organic solvents, such as CH2Cl2, CHCl3, THF, and C6H6. The structure of HL was determined by 1H NMR, IR, elemental analysis, and X-ray single-crystal analysis. The IR spectrum of HL showed a -CN absorption band at 2250 cm-1. In the 1H NMR spectrum of HL, the proton resonance was observed at 17.75 ppm as a singlet. It is attributed to the chelated proton, which is hydrogen bonded to the neighbor carbonyl on the 1-benzoyl group. The IR spectrum of HL does not show absorption above 1630 cm-1 in the region normally assigned to organic carbonyl groups. However, the strong absorption band at 1615 cm-1 is consistent with the hydrogen-bonded enol structure since it has been shown that conjugation and chelation lead to a large shift of the carbonyl infrared band. So HL exists in the form of fulvene, which is one of the most important moieties in organomtallic chemistry. The structure of HL was further confirmed by X-ray diffraction techniques. The corresponding molecular structures of HL are shown in Figure . As shown in Figure , the molecular structure of HL reveals that the two aroyl groups on the substituted cyclopetadienyl ring are adjacent. The C−C bond lengths on the substituted Cp-ring and also C(1)−C(2) and C(6)−C(7) range from 1.377(2) to 1.465(2) Å, which are significantly shorter than a normal C−C single bond distance. The enol hydrogen atom (H(1)) is hydrogen bonded to the carbonyl oxygen atom (O(2), d (O(2) ··· H(1)) = 1.35(3) Å, ∠O(1)−H(1)···O(2) = 171(2)° and d O(1) ··· O(2) = 2.452(18) Å) to provide a hydrogen bonded seven-membered ring. In the solid state, two m−CN functional groups on HL are oriented in the reserve directions, and the terminal (-CN) N···N separation is 14.64(5) Å. In addition to the two -CN groups, the carbonyl and enol groups in HL could act as potential chelating coordinating sites to bind transition metal ions into seven-membered metallo-ring containing complexes; they could also be potentially transferred to other types of organic functional groups, such as heterocyclic rings, by reaction with hydroxylamine, hydrazine, or the like.

Results and Discussion

 Structural Analysis of HL. Ligand HL was prepared in moderate yield as an orange crystalline solid by the reaction of 3-cyanobenzoyl chloride with corresponding alkyl-substituted cyclopentadienyl anion, which derived from 6,6‘-dimethylenefulvene and 4-biphenyllithium in ether at 0 °C (Scheme ). HL is soluble in common organic solvents, such as CH2Cl2, CHCl3, THF, and C6H6. The structure of HL was determined by 1H  NMR, IR, elemental analysis, and X-ray single-crystal analysis. The IR spectrum of HL showed a -CN absorption band at 2250 cm-1. In the 1H NMR spectrum of HL, the proton resonance was observed at 17.75 ppm as a singlet. It is attributed to the chelated proton, which is hydrogen bonded to the neighbor carbonyl on the 1-benzoyl group. The IR spectrum of HL does not show absorption above 1630 cm-1 in the region normally assigned to organic carbonyl groups. However, the strong absorption band at 1615 cm-1 is consistent with the hydrogen-bonded enol structure since it has been shown that conjugation and chelation lead to a large shift of the carbonyl infrared band. So HL exists in the form of fulvene, which is one of the most important moieties in organomtallic chemistry. The structure of HL was further confirmed by X-ray diffraction techniques. The corresponding molecular structures of HL are shown in Figure . As shown in Figure , the molecular structure of HL reveals that the two aroyl groups on the substituted cyclopetadienyl ring are adjacent. The C-C bond lengths on the substituted Cp-ring and also C(1)-C(2) and C(6)-C(7) range from 1.377(2) to 1.465(2) Å, which are significantly shorter than a normal C-C single bond distance. The enol hydrogen atom (H(1)) is hydrogen bonded to the carbonyl oxygen atom (O(2), d (O(2) ⋅⋅⋅ H(1)) = 1.35(3) Å, ∠O(1)-H(1)⋅⋅⋅O(2) = 171(2)° and d O(1) ⋅⋅⋅ O(2) = 2.452(18) Å) to provide a hydrogen bonded seven-membered ring. In the solid state, two m-CN functional groups on HL are oriented in the reserve directions, and the terminal (-CN) N⋅⋅⋅N separation is 14.64(5) Å. In addition to the two -CN groups, the carbonyl and enol groups in HL could act as potential chelating coordinating sites to bind transition metal ions into seven-membered metallo-ring containing complexes; they could also be potentially transferred to other types of organic functional groups, such as heterocyclic rings, by reaction with hydroxylamine, hydrazine, or the like.

elements.content: Structural analysis of 1. Ag(I)-containing polymeric compound 1, namely, [Ag(HL)(H2O)]SbF6, was synthesized by combination of HL and AgSbF6 in benzene at ambient temperature in 74% yield. Crystals of 1 are air stable. Single-crystal analysis revealed, as shown in Figure , that compound 1 crystallizes in the space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit consists of one Ag(I) center, one HL ligand, a coordinated H2O molecule, and the SbF6 - anion. Each Ag(I) center in 1 adopts a {AgC2N2O} oragnometallic pseudotetrahedral coordination environment, which consists of two carbon atoms (C(30) and C(31)) from biphenyl functional group, one aquo oxygen atom (Ag(1)−O(3) = 2.432(5) Å), and two nitrogen donors (Ag(1)−N(1) = 2.176(5) and Ag(1)−N(2) = 2.199(4) Å) from two -CN groups on two HL ligands. For the Ag(I) center, the two Ag−Cbenzene bond distances (2.716(5) and 2.806(5) Å) lie in the range of normal Ag−C bond distances 2.47−2.86 Å, while the remaining Ag−C distances are longer than 2.86 Å, which is beyond the limits commonly observed in Ag(I)-aromatic complexes. Thus, the biphenyl ring in 1 coordinates to the Ag(I) ion with an η2 instead of an η1 bonding mode, which is normally observed in arene−silver(I) complexes.

elements.content: In the solid state, Ag(I) centers are connected to each other by HL through two terminal N-donors into novel one-dimensional undulating chains extending along crystallographic a-axis (Figure ). It is interesting that the biphenyl substituent group on HL reaches near the Ag(I) center and binds it by a π−Ag(I) interaction to form a 18-membered orgnaometallic loop, which makes the whole chain exhibit a molecular beaded motif. The shortest intrachain Ag···Ag distance is 17.83(12) Å. The uncoordinated SbF6 - counterions (shortest Ag···F distance 4.399(7) Å) are located between chains and serve to link two nearby one-dimensional beaded chains into double chains through two sets of O−H···F H-bonding systems (O(3)···F(2) = 3.038(7) and H(3B)···F(2) = 2.26(5) Å, ∠O(3)−H(3B)···F(2) = 164(7)° and O(3)···F(1) = 2.782(6) and H(3A)···F(1) = 1.98(5) Å, ∠O(3)−H(3A)···F(1) = 173(7)°) (Figure ). The shortest interchain Ag···Ag distance is 9.93(12) Å. It is worthwhile to point out that the coordination chemistry of 3,3‘-bibenzonitrile ligands of this type with the Ag(I) metal template appear to be quite versatile. They can adopt a cis- and trans-conformation to bind the Ag(I) metal ion into a one-, two-, or three-dimensional framework. For example, cis-3,3‘-bibenzonitrile fulvene ligands could serve as U-shaped spacers to bind Ag(I) centers into either a one-dimensional CpAg(I)-containing organometallic coordination polymer5d or a two-dimensional network with square-like motif. trans-3, 3‘-Bibenzonitrile fulvene ligands, on the other hand, could act as Z-shaped spacers to link Ag(I) metal centers into either a one-dimensional undulating chain5b or a three-dimensional diamondoid framework. HL reported herein adopts a transoid conformation to coordinate the Ag(I) center in 1. As noted previously, one trans-oriented -CN donor and cocoordianted 4-biphenyl group are facing in the same direction, which allows HL to bind Ag(I) centers as an organometallic molecular clip to form a novel intramolecular organometallic loop that is further connected to each other into a novel beaded one-dimensional chain by cooperation of the other terminal -CN donor. Such kinds of coordination behavior are not observed in our previous study of these types of fulvene ligands.

elements.content: It is worthwhile to point out that, in these specific reactions, the products do not depend on the ligand-to-metal ratio. The single crystals of 1 and 2 chosen for X-ray single-crystal analysis were representative of the bulk materials confirmed by the agreement between the simulated X-ray powder diffraction pattern generated from the single-crystal data and the experimental pattern measured on powdered samples of the remaining crystals of 1 and 2, respectively. However, increasing the ligand-to-metal ratio resulted in a somewhat higher yield and higher crystal quality.

elements.content: Structural Analysis of 2. Complex 2 was synthesized by solution reaction between the new ligand HL and Co(OAc)2·2H2O in hot ethanol. When a solution of HL in ethanol was treated with Co(OAc)2·2H2O, in a metal-to-ligand molar ratio of 1:2, compound 2 was obtained as the neutral molecular compound with a seven-membered metallo-ring. It is worth pointing out that the coordination chemistry 2 with transition metal template Co(II) is independent of the metal-to-ligand mole ratio. For example, when the metal-to-ligand ratio changed from 1:1 to 2:1, even 3:1, compound 2 is always isolated as the only product. Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic system. Co(II) center is on the inversion center. As shown in Figure , the Co(II) center lies in an octahedral coordination environment defined by four O-donors from two bidentate ligand L and two O-donors from two coordinated ethanol solvent molecules. The octahedral coordination polyhedron is slightly distorted, where all angles around the cobalt center deviate significantly from 90° (O(2)−Co−O(1) = 88.58(10)°, O(2)#1−Co−O(3)#1= 92.21(10)°, and O(1)−Co−O(3)#1 = 94.31(11)°). The Co−O bond distances on the basal plane are 2.012(2) and 2.018(2) Å, respectively, which compare well with the Co−O distance found in cobalt−oxygen complexes. The distances between the cobalt center atom and the two axial O-donor atoms are the same (d Co - O = 2.143(3) Å), again consistent with corresponding bond lengths in those complexes with a similar coordination envoronment. It is well-known that neutral or deprotoned 1,2-diketone or 1,3-diketone compounds can be the chelating ligands to bind transition metal ions into five- or six-membered metallo-ring systems that engender less strain because the atoms on the rings are allowed to adopt more closely their natural bond angles. It is much less known that seven-membered metallo-ring complexes generated from neutral or deprotoned 1,4-diketone-containing ligands and transition metal ions are probably due to the conformational strain effect. However, there are still some interesting seven-membered metallacycle complexes reported recently, such as metal complexes generated from TADDOL, diazoacetate, bis(phosphane) ligands, and related bidentate chelating ligands. Some of them are demonstrated to be very useful catalysts in metal-catalyzed stereoselective syntheses. HL herein presented one more perfect example for the synthesis of seven-membered metallo-ring transition metal complexes because of its specific molecular geometry. In 2, the carbon−carbon bond distances on the substituted Cp-ring and also its exocyclic carbon−carbon double bonds are almost identical as their corresponding bond lengths in the free HL (ranging from 1.377(2) to 1.456(2) Å). The four −CN groups in 2 are uncoordinated, and every two of them are oriented in the same direction but in the reverse direction to each other. The IR spectrum of 2 shows that the −C⋮N stretch (2255 cm-1) was essentially unchanged from free HL, which can be taken as evidence for the nitrile nitrogen not entering the coordination sphere of the Co(II) center. A similar phenomenon occurs in the reaction of Ru2(O2C(CH2)6CH3)4 in toluene and Cu(hfacac)2·H2O (hfacac = hexafluoroacetylacetonate) in methylene chloride with 4-cyanopyridine and 3-cyanopyridine, respectively. The discrete molecular 1:2 adduct Ru2(O2C(CH2)6CH3)4(4-cyanopyridine)2 and Cu(hfacac)2(3-cyanopyridine)2 are obtained instead of the expected 4-cyanopyridine and 3-cyanopyridine bridged transition metal complexes. It is known that 4-cyanopyridine and 3-cyanopyridine spacers have been used as bridging ligands to link transition metal species into dimers and polymers. It appears that the nitrile N-donor atom has a poor coordinating ability to effectively link 3d metal ions. For example, in [(Cu(4-cyanopyridine)4(H2O)(ClO4)2) n , the nitrile nitrogen only weakly coordinates with copper centers through a semicoordinated bond (Cu−N⋮C is 2.649(4)Å), which is much longer than a normal Cu−N coordinative bond. It is worth noting that 2 contains uncoordinated N-donors that could be used as a potential new metal-containing building blocks, as suggested by us recently. These building blocks could be connected by other suitable metal ions (i.e., Ag+ or Cd2+) or unsaturated metal complexes via bonding interactions with the free nitrile nitrogen atoms in 2, a direction we are pursuing.

elements.content: In the solid state, the H-bonded one-dimensional chain motif was found in 2. As shown in Figure , the neutral building blocks 2 arrange parallel to the crystallographic b-axis and moreover are bound together by strong intermolecular N···O−H hydrogen bonds in a hand-in-hand fashion to create a one-dimensional chain motif along crystallographic b-axis. The hydrogen bonding system in 2 consists of the one uncoordinated nitrogen atom on the −CN group with the hydrogen atom on the coordinated ethanol molecule oxygen atom of a neighboring Co(II) complexes. The N···H and O···N distances are 1.97(5) and 2.892(5) Å, respectively, and the corresponding O−H···N angle is 172(4)°. The existence and structural importance of strong hydrogen-bonding interactions generated from -CN (as the hydrogen bond acceptor) are now well-established and observed in many compounds. It is no doubt for these strong hydrogen bonding interactions to contribute significantly to the alignment of the molecules of 2 in the crystalline state. The intrachain Co···Co is 10.80(3) Å.

elements.content: Luminescent Properties. Mixed inorganic−organic hybrid supramolecular coordination compounds have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Owing to the ability of affecting the emission wavelength of organic materials, syntheses of inorganic−organic coordination supramolecular complexes by the judicious choice of organic spacers and transition metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of electroluminescent materials. The luminescent properties of HL and 1 and 2 were investigated in the solid state. The fluorescence spectrum of HL is shown in Figure and exhibits one emission maximum at 529 nm. The emission spectrum of 1, also shown in Figure , is red-shifted to 557 nm, with a second, less intense band present at 590 nm. The emission spectrum of 2 exhibits one emission maximum at 530 nm (Figure ), which is almost identical with that of HL. Slight enhancement of the fluorescence intensities is realized in both compounds 1 and 2. The emission color of the free HL was significantly affected by its incorporation into the Ag(I)-containing polymeric compound 1, as evidenced by the large shift in the emission.

The luminescent properties of HL and 1 and 2 were investigated in the solid state. The fluorescence spectrum of HL is shown in Figure  and exhibits one emission maximum at 529 nm. The emission spectrum of 1, also shown in Figure , is red-shifted to 557 nm, with a second, less intense band present at 590 nm. The emission spectrum of 2 exhibits one emission maximum at 530 nm (Figure ), which is almost identical with that of HL. Slight enhancement of the fluorescence intensities is realized in both compounds 1 and 2. The emission color of the free HL was significantly affected by its incorporation  into the Ag(I)-containing polymeric compound 1, as evidenced by the large shift in the emission.

elements.content: Conclusions. One new fulvene-type ligand HL was synthesized successfully by aroylation reaction of substituted cyclopentadienyl anions. The coordination chemistry of HL is investigated. The study demonstrated that a new fulvene-type ligand HL could be used as polydentate or chelating ligand to coordinate transition metal ions into a coordination polymer or supramolecular complex. One novel one-dimensional Ag(I)-fulvene coordination polymer (1) containing an organometallic Ag(I)-loop moiety and one Co(II) complex (2) with an unusual seven-membered metallo-ring unit were synthesized successfully based on it. In the solid state, complex 2 adopts a novel hydrogen bonded one-dimensional chain motif. We are currently extending this result by preparing new fulvene ligands of this type with different substituted organic functional groups. We anticipate this approach to be useful for the construction of a variety of new transition metal complexes and coordination polymers (including bimetallic polymeric compounds) with novel structures.

In the solid state, complex 2 adopts a novel hydrogen bonded one-dimensional chain motif. We are currently extending this result by preparing new fulvene ligands of this type with different substituted organic functional groups. We anticipate this approach to be useful for the construction of a variety of new transition metal complexes and coordination polymers (including bimetallic polymeric compounds) with novel structures.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of HL. A solution of 3-cyanobenzoyl chloride (2.00 g, 12.5 mmol) in anhydrous ether (20 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of substituted cyclopentadienyl anion (18.8 mmol) in anhydrous ether at 0 °C, which was derived from 6,6‘-dimethylenefulvene (18.8 mmol) and 4-biphenyllithium (18.8 mmol) in anhydrous ether. The mixture was stirred overnight at room temperature. The solvent was then reduced to about 10 mL under vacuum. Hexane was added, and an orange solid precipitated. The solid was washed with hexane several times and stirred in HCl (5% in water) overnight. The final product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (CH2Cl2 /hexane, 2:1) to afford an orange crystalline solid (1.73 g, 56%). IR (KBr pellet) ν (cm-1) = 3100(w), 2990(m), 2250(vs), 1620(vs), 1590(vs), 1555(vs), 1525(s), 1485(vs), 1445(s), 1365(s), 1350(s), 1200(s), 1120(s), 1100(s), 935(s), 915(m), 800(m), 765(m), 730(m), 695(m). 1H NMR (90 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C, TMS):  δ = 17.75 (s, 1H, OH), 7.9−7.2 (m, 19H, -biphenyl), 6.97 (s, 2H, -C5H2), 1.60 (s, 6H, -CH3). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C36H26O2N2:  C 83.30, H 5.01, N 5.40; found:  C 83.69, H 5.26, N 5.32.

Synthesis of 1. AgSbF6 (12.0 mg, 0.035 mmol) was added to a solution of HL (15.5 mg, 0.03 mmol) in 15 mL of benzene. After about 30 min of stirring at room temperature, the mixture was heated under reflux for several minutes. After filtering, the resultant yellow solution was introduced into a 7 mm diameter tube. After the sample stood at room temperature for around one week, yellow crystals of 1 were obtained (59%). IR (KBr pellet) ν (cm-1) = 2980(s), 2850(m), 2295(s), 2255(s), 1620(vs), 1550(vs), 1520(vs), 1415(vs), 1350(vs), 1200(s), 1170(s), 1100(m), 930(m), 765(s), 655(vs). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C36H28AgF6N2O3Sb:  C 49.08, H 3.18, N 3.18; found:  C 49.28, H 3.51, N 3.35.

Synthesis of 2. A mixture of HL (10.4 mg, 0.02 mmol) and Co(OAc)2·2H2O (3.0 mg, 0.01 mmol) in anhydrous EtOH (15 mL) was refluxed for 5 min and allowed to cool. The clear red solution was allowed to stand at room temperature for about one week. Deep red crystals of 2 were obtained, and they were washed with hexane and dried in air (90%). IR (KBr pellet) ν (cm-1) = 3500(br), 3105(w), 2990(m), 2850(m), 2255(s), 1585(s), 1565(vs), 1525(s), 1445(m), 1410(s), 1360(m), 1325(s), 1200(w), 1140(w), 1120(w), 1095(w), 910(w), 765(m), 730(m), 690(w). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C76H62CoN4O6:  C 77.75, H 4.43, N 4.77; found:  C 77.50, H 4.23, N 4.85.

cln_elements.content: Luminescent Properties. Mixed inorganic−organic hybrid supramolecular coordination compounds have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Owing to the ability of affecting the emission wavelength of organic materials, syntheses of inorganic−organic coordination supramolecular complexes by the judicious choice of organic spacers and transition metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of electroluminescent materials. The luminescent properties of HL and 1 and 2 were investigated in the solid state. The fluorescence spectrum of HL is shown in Figure and exhibits one emission maximum at 529 nm. The emission spectrum of 1, also shown in Figure , is red-shifted to 557 nm, with a second, less intense band present at 590 nm. The emission spectrum of 2 exhibits one emission maximum at 530 nm (Figure ), which is almost identical with that of HL. Slight enhancement of the fluorescence intensities is realized in both compounds 1 and 2. The emission color of the free HL was significantly affected by its incorporation into the Ag(I)-containing polymeric compound 1, as evidenced by the large shift in the emission.
